user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of connection_check_timedout:
```c
static bool
connection_check_timedout (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  const uint64_t timeout = c->connection_timeout_ms;
  uint64_t now;
  uint64_t since_actv;

  if (c->suspended)
    return false;
  if (0 == timeout)
    return false;
  now = MHD_monotonic_msec_counter ();
  since_actv = now - c->last_activity;
  /* Keep the next lines in sync with #connection_get_wait() to avoid
   * undesired side-effects like busy-waiting. */
  if (timeout < since_actv)
  {
    if (UINT64_MAX / 2 < since_actv)
    {
      const uint64_t jump_back = c->last_activity - now;
      /* Very unlikely that it is more than quarter-million years pause.
       * More likely that system clock jumps back. */
      if (5000 >= jump_back)
      {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
        MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
                  _ ("Detected system clock %u milliseconds jump back.\n"),
                  (unsigned int) jump_back);
#endif
        return false;
      }
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
      MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
                _ ("Detected too large system clock %" PRIu64 " milliseconds "
                   "jump back.\n"),
                jump_back);
#endif
    }
    return true;
  }
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
      MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
                _ ("Detected too large system clock %" PRIu64 " milliseconds "
                   "jump back.\n"),
                jump_back);
#endif

#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
        MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
                  _ ("Detected system clock %u milliseconds jump back.\n"),
                  (unsigned int) jump_back);
#endif

/* Keep the next lines in sync with #connection_get_wait() to avoid
   * undesired side-effects like busy-waiting. */
explanation: I selected all code fragments that invoke other functions or macros that could potentially lead (directly or indirectly) back to connection_check_timedout, and one comment that explicitly references another function (connection_get_wait) implying a relationship that should be checked for indirect recursion. Other parts of the function do not require investigation for Rule 17.2 because they contain only: simple member accesses (e.g. c->suspended, c->connection_timeout_ms, c->last_activity, c->daemon), constant checks (e.g. 0 == timeout, UINT64_MAX / 2 < since_actv), pure arithmetic/subtraction, comparisons, return statements, variable declarations, and comments. None of those are function calls and therefore cannot produce direct or indirect recursion by themselves. The PRIu64 token is a printf format macro, not a function call, so it is not a recursion risk. No direct call to connection_check_timedout appears in the code, so the remaining investigation should focus on the listed fragments (the monotonic clock call, logging calls, and the noted relationship to connection_get_wait) to determine whether any of them (or functions they call) could, directly or indirectly, call connection_check_timedout.
